data.title: Lake effect snow warnings are in effect starting Monday night
data.text:
The next couple days are shaping up to be quite snowy as the National Weather Service has issued Lake Effect Snow Warnings and Winter Storm Watches for our northern counties starting Monday afternoon.

A strong system is currently crossing the Great Lakes region that will bring a quick hit of rain to Syracuse overnight. The main effect this system will have is the strong westerly winds it'll produce after it passes by. That'll ramp up lake effect snow showers through Wednesday morning for the area.

Let's knock out timing of the snow accumulation. By Monday night, relatively light accumulation across the lower elevations with a couple inches possible for the Tug Hill Plateau.

Tuesday morning, the persistent lake effect snow band will continue to drop heavy snow in the higher elevations with accumulation beginning to mount for central Oswego County.

By Tuesday afternoon, lake effect snow will push south towards Syracuse with light to moderate snow during overnight hours on Wednesday.

By Wednesday morning, 2-4" of snow accumulation is possible in Syracuse with gradually higher snowfall totals the further north you are.

By Wednesday afternoon southwesterly winds should help escort the lake effect snow north of the area.

Total snowfall accumulation through Wednesday afternoon:

Oswego: 4-8"

Syracuse: 2-4"

Tug Hill region: 12-20"

Pulaski: 5-10"

Rome: 3-6"

Utica: 2-5"

Skaneateles: 1-3"

These accumulation numbers will likely change a bit with updated model runs tonight and tomorrow.
